item.description:
Report E-2024110126

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-09T00:55:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-31
  • City: DES PLAINES
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately one (1) pint releasee from four (4) one (1) pint cans of SikaBiresin® CH910-2 Blade Repair Part B, impacting the trailer floor. The release was due to the product being crushed by other freight. Dayton Freight personnel advised they cleaned and neutralized impacted area. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

Origin Criterion: A, Blanket Period 26/07/2024 to 26/07/2025." SDS provided by the shipper. Inner contents: 1 plastic bottle @2 lbs. of 100% Sodium Hydroxide (Food Grade) (Lye, Caustic Soda), Belle chemical, LLC, Billings MT. Bellechemical.com, 877-522-2233. NO RELEASE. Shipment is being held for FAA investigation.

item.title: Report X-2024110103
item.description:
Report X-2024110103

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-08T12:22:42+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-04
  • City: SPOKANE
  • State: WA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 11/4/2024 at approximately 1015, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 240946 at the station location in Spokane, reporting undeclared dangerous goods. The shipment consisted of 4 plastic bottles, packaged in a fiberboard box. The shipment was discovered emitting an odor during sort. Further investigation revealed a stain along the bottom of the box. Upon examining the inner contents, one of the bottles appeared damp around the closure. A safety data sheet found inside of the packaging classified the commodity as UN3082. It appears the shipment was tendered under IATA Special Provisions A197; however, the packaging of the shipment did not comply with IATA 5.0.2.6.1.3 and 5.0.2.8., not having sufficient closure, ullage, or absorbent material. The shipment is being held for an FAA investigation.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On October 29, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN3098 was punctured and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the trailer floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. HCE deployed granular absorbents on the impacted dock floor and began utilizing hand tools to collect spent absorbents into one (1) 55-gallon drum. The crew damaged pail into tone (1) 30-gallon drum. HCE staged the waste on site for further management.

R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. item.title: Report E-2024110112
item.description:
Report E-2024110112

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-08T12:22:42+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-29
  • City: SAUGET
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On October 29, 2024, one (1) 275-gallon tote of UN3267 was damaged in transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from ES+ to remediate the site. ES+ personnel deployed granular absorbents to the UN3267-impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum. E3 personnel transferred the product from the 275-gallon tote to a 330-gallon tote to be shipped off to its destination. The damaged tote was cut up and placed into one (1) 55-gallon drum. All waste was staged onsite for future disposal by CES personnel.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On October 28, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of printer ink was damaged by a forklift and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from GrayMar Environmental Services (GES) to remediate the impacted site. The crew utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the impacted site and disposed of them into a drum liner. The damaged drum was containerized in one (1) 95-gallon drum for disposal.

  • City: ELKHART

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed a four and a half (4.5) gallon release of product, it was advised the trailer arrived with the product released. The terminal personnel cleaned release using Oil Dri absorbent. Dayton Freight completed cleanup and generated two (2) ten (10) gallon poly drum of waste, one containing spent absorbent and product. The other contained the damaged can container was placed into a separate 10-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.description:
Report E-2024100528

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-08T12:22:42+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-09
  • City: Nashville
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 10/9/24, at 04:37 personnel in the CSXT Radnor discovered SHPX221329, a residue tank car of Butadiene, leaking from top of the car. The car was isolated and the shipper, BASF, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2024-1009-00030). Marion Environmental Inc. (MEI), a CSXT response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found the B-end liquid valve partially open and the Drylok-style secondary securement not containing the release. Contractor personnel closed the valve and stopped the release. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper's representative (Scott McDonald, 409 981-5133). The car was subsequently held at Radnor Yard until the secondary closure was replaced and an OTMA-1 was submitted and approved by the FRA.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight Lines personnel observed approximately one (1) pint of Sodium Bromide released from one (1) plastic bucket due to improper handling. The release impacted the concrete dock floor. Dayton Freight personnel cleaned up the spill using Oil Dri absorbent. Personnel completed cleanup and generated one (1) four (4) gallon plastic drum of waste containing the spilled product and spent absorbents. Dayton Freight also generated one (1) ten (10) gallon plastic drum of waste containing the punctured bucket. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Upon arrival at the intermediate terminal, it was discovered that the tote cap had failed in transit. Investigation revealed that the small inner cap of the tote cap was missing and material had sprayed up to the roof of the van trailer. The released material was contained to inside the trailer. The released material was neutralized and cleaned up by a cleanup contractor. The cleaned up material was containerized for proper disposal. The tote cap was replaced with a new vented tote cap and the tote was sent on to destination. Based on the evidence, it is our assumption that this was a faulty vent cap that failed in transit.

  • Description: At 0304 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at terminal BIN. It was reported that approximately 220-gallons of UN1903 released from a plastic tote due to a forklift puncture. The release impacted concrete dock floor. Contractors arrived on site applying absorbent to solidify the impacted areas of the dock floor. All spent absorbent and debris were containerized into (7) 55-gallon metal drums. Contractors used poly containers to recoup good product which was then transferred into a new 275-gallon tote - (approximately 150-gallons of product). The waste was staged onsite for terminal to manage.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-07T12:22:36+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-04
  • City: NEWARK
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 11/3/2024 at approximately 2145, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 435751 at the ramp facility in Newark, reporting a dangerous goods spill. The shipment consisted of 3 glass bottles, each containing 8 oz of liquid, packaged in one fiberboard box. Due to human error, the shipment began to feel damp. Further investigation revealed that one of the bottles had broken, resulting in spillage. The damaged bottle was placed in a salvage drum for disposal and the remaining shipment was placed in a separate drum and awaits an amended Shipper's declaration for further transport.

item.title: Report E-2024110037
item.description:
Report E-2024110037

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-07T12:22:36+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-03
  • City: SHREVEPORT
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 8000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On November 3, 2024, at 0533 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Shreveport, Louisiana regarding the release of Phosphoric Acid Solution. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of 30 gallons of Phosphoric Acid Solution (UN1805, 8, III) from (1) 60-gallon plastic drum onto the trailer floor and outside pavement. The release was reportedly due to a puncture from a pallet, impacting a 17’ x 8’ area in the trailer and 7’ x 100’ area on the pavement. No drains or waterways were impacted by the release. The release was neutralized then cleaned up with absorbents and the proper PPE. The damaged drum with the remaining product was placed into an overpack to move on with the client. Undamaged products were re-loaded and re-secured in the trailer. All waste generated from addressing this release was containerized in (7) 55-gallon DF, which were then staged onsite by the contractor for proper disposal.

THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX TO INDICATE DRY ICE WAS BEING SHIPPED AIR SERVICE. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

Once we received all signatures on the hazardous waste manifest we were able to process the material has hazardous waste (waste printing ink related material)

item.title: Report I-2024110016
item.description:
Report I-2024110016

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-07T12:22:36+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-09
  • City: El Cajon
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: COASTAL TRANSPORT CO.,. INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 2607950
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: CTMV was stopped at traffic signal on Navaho Road. When the light turned green, the operator began accelerating to make 90 degree left tum onto Fletcher Parkway. The tum is an"off-camber turn" as the outer tum radius surface is lower than the inner tum radius. The driver failed to respond correctly to this surface condition. As the CTMV turned, the liquid cargo surged to the passenger side of the cargo compartments. The sudden weight shift caused the CTMV to roll over to the right. The CTMV rotated 180 degrees clockwise and came to rest upside down straddling the roadway and sidewalk. Fuel began Ieaking through the venting devices mounted between the rollover rails on the top of the semi-trailer. The fuel flowed downhill along the sidewalk and curb. Fuel entered two storm drain entry points before the entry points were closed by sand bagging. The storm drain was dry down stream. While upside down, the compartments were tapped, and approximately 400 gallons were recovered from the compartments. Fuel recovery and remediation steps were begun immediately. Approximately 1500 gallons were recovered from a concrete utility pit located within the sidewalk underneath the upside down CTMV. The remaining fuel is being recovered by cleaning the storm drain conduit and replacing soil that has absorbed fuel downstream from the spill site. Asphalt roadway surface is being replaced for approximately 200 feet downhill from the spill site. The fuel did not enter any waterway.

item.title: Report E-2024110054
item.description:
Report E-2024110054

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-07T12:22:36+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-08
  • City: UHRICHSVILLE
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 1907 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at XUR. It was reported that approximately 1 ounce of Potassium perchlorate released from a 50-pound plastic bag due to improper loading by the shipper. The bag has a rip in it and is still wrapped on the pallet. The release impacted trailer #4633605 at dock door 14. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-ounces of Potassium Perchlorate product released to a 1x1’ area of the trailer floor due to bag being overfilled and excess product leaking from seam. They added cardboard bracing behind shrink-wrap to the area which had the release underneath, to add as extra layer of protection. The contractors containerized floor sweepings of product into (1) 55-gallon metal drum (with vented bung caps). The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2024110043
item.description:
Report E-2024110043

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-07T12:22:36+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-08
  • City: PHOENIX
  • State: AZ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: 10/8 XPO Logistics terminal UPH experienced a UN1993 Unisol Liquid Red BK-50 release from 250-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractor to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 4-ounces of product released to 1' x 1' area of cardboard on the dock floor. The tote was leaking due to a small pinhole in the body. The tote was patched for future transfer. Crew returned on 10/17 once the new metal tote from the shipper was onsite. The crew transferred the product from the damaged tote into the new one for shipment on. The damaged metal tote was staged to be returned to the shipper. All impacted pads, PPE, and cleanup debris were containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

The spill consists of approximately 5 or more gallons of Flurospar White, which released from (1) 275-gallon metal tote due to a missing lid, causing the tote to slosh and splash during transit. The paint is all over the top of the tote and has spread out to the sides and the floor of the trailer as well. Contractors confirmed 1-gallon of material had been released and transferred into a 330-gallon plastic tote. The old tote was cleaned and wiped down, released material was cleaned up on the trailer floor and walls and the waste material, impacted granular absorbents, pads, PPE, plastic and PVC tube were placed into (1) 55-gallon metal drum. The waste was staged on site for terminal to manage.

item.title: Report E-2024110017
item.description:
Report E-2024110017

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-06T12:32:05+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-01
  • City: HENDERSON
  • State: CO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal UDV experienced a UN2924 ACPC22154A release from (2) 55-gallon metal drums. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 10 ounces of product released to a 3’ x 2’ area of the wood trailer floor. The caps on the drums were leaking due to possible overfilling. The damaged drums were each placed into a 95-gallon poly overpack. Absorbents were deployed to clean the impacted area and then collected into a 30-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

Report E-2024110015

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-06T12:32:05+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-28
  • City: MARSHFIELD
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On October 28, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN3264 leaked in transit and released approximately six (6) ounces of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EX Environmental (EXE) to remediate the impacted site. EX personnel utilized absorbent pads and soda ash to remediate the impacted trailer. Crews tightened the cap and secured the 55-gallon drum of UN3264 for further shipment and transport. All PPE and spent absorbents were collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and take offsite by EX personnel.

ALL NINE BOXES HAVE BEEN COMPLETELY SEALED IN SECURITY TAPE. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON ANY OF THE OUTER BOXES. THE PHONES HAVE STICKERS APPLIED DESCRIBING PHYSICAL AND/OR INTERNAL ASSESSMENTS SUCH AS NOTED DAMAGE, DEFECTS AND BATTERY HEALTH. ADDITIONAL TRACKING NUMBERS IN THE MULTI PIECE SHIPMENT TO HONG KONG ARE 1Z6X37F90411825022, 1Z6X37F90401098793, 1Z6X37F90413388831, 1Z6X37F90400476368, 1Z6X37F90400924007, 1Z6X37F90401086840, 1Z6X37F90402631418 AND 1Z6X37F90419231784. item.title: Report E-2024110006
item.description:
Report E-2024110006

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-05T12:22:11+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-07
  • City: HERCULES
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On October 7, Veolia employees were collecting drums from the customer's site. To create space for additional drums in Veolia's truck, a Veolia employee began stacking empty 55 gallon containers that were already loaded in the truck. The Veolia employee misjudged the weight of one drum, assuming it contained residual waste when it actually weighed approximately 60 pounds. As a result, the drum slipped out of his hands, fell, and was punctured at the bottom when it struck a metal panel attached to the truck. Approximately 1 liter of fluid spilled from the drum. Spill pads were immediately placed to contain the spill and the spill was reported internally to request additional personnel to assist with the cleanup. At approximately 2:30PM (estimate), additional Veolia employees arrived to apply a hydrofluoric acid eater to the spill area along with the necessary PPE for proper management. No spill was released outside of the truck.

item.title: Report I-2024100108
item.description:
Report I-2024100108

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-05T12:22:11+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-04
  • City: DAYTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ROSS TRANSPORTATION SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: As reported by Univar Operations Manager ..... . "Ross Transportation Services arrived at the Dayton branch to transport waste to Ross from Dayton. When the warehouse worker inspected the trailer to load he found liquid on the floor of the trailer. At the time there was no waste leaking from the trailer. The Ross driver was advised of the leaker and asked to pull out of the dock into the truck lot where we placed containment under the trailer to keep any of the waste from reaching the ground. At this point we have not determined which container is leaking for sure but believe it to by a flammable hazardous waste that is contained in a .275 gallon tote. It appears to be a very slow leak since none is escaping the trailer and the floor does not showing signs of significant leaking. Four totes of the same profile are loaded onto the rear of the Ross trailer. NRC was contacted for emergency response to handle the leaker and any clean up required. The ETA for the clean up contractor is 3:00 pm ET. There has been no exposure of employees nor any release to the ground. ER crew arrived on site and we determined the leaker was actually a DM of profile E80-9351A RIS which is a hazardous waste which is a flammable liquid, toxic and corrosive. It looks like less than a gallon escaped onto the trailer floor. The drum had a hole in the lower portion of the side of the drum which was allowing a very slow leak of the contents. The crew overpacked the drum using an overpack from Dayton branch. They used floor dry to clean up the trailer floor and placed the floor dry in the overpack with the drum. The overpack was labeled and loaded Back on the Ross trailer. The Dayton customer waste is being loaded onto the Ross trailer for shipment to Ross."

  • Description: On 10/01/2024, at 0823 hours, personnel at the CSXT Selkirk, NY yard reported DOWX 74341, a loaded tank car containing Combustible liquids N.O.S. (Diethylene Glycol Monoethyl Ether), leaking from bottom of the tank car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Union Carbide, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report #2024-10-01-00216). HEPACO, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found two of the eight bolts bottom outlet mounting flange bolts were less than tool tight. HEPACO inspected the bottom outlet valve to ensure there were no additional defects and secured all of the bolts tool tight to stop the release. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative (Bryan Hopkins Ph# 989-636-1483). The car was held out of transportation pending further work and movement to home shop for a certified repair.

item.title: Report E-2024100689
item.description:
Report E-2024100689

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-05T12:22:11+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-01
  • City: SPRING HILL
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: AMERIGAS PROPANE, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 115050
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: S&L Company Transport driver started his workday at 1753 on 9/31/2024. He drove from his parking location at 15222 Hudson Ave., Spring Hill, FL to the Orlando, FL terminal to load his truck. He made two deliveries - the first being in Palmetto, FL at an AmeriGas facility, and the last being in Clearwater a the AmeriGas facility. When Transport Driver completed the final delivery in Clearwater, he drove back to his parking location at 15222 Hudson Ave., Spring Hill, FL, which is an AmeriGas property. To access this location, the Transport Driver backs in off the roadway to get into the yard. On this morning at 0522, he pulled up headed westbound on Hudson Ave. and began his backing maneuver traveling 3 mph. He was across both lanes of traffic in the middle of his maneuver when a 3rd party vehicle traveling eastbound on Hudson Ave. crashed into the transport trailer. The Transport Driver immediately got out of the vehicle to assess the situation and called 911. When emergency personnel arrived on scene, the scene was secured and the leak was assessed. There was a small leak coming from the flange of the pump under the transport and emergency personnel and AmeriGas decided it would be best to evacuate the remaining propane in the transport by flaring it off. The responding fire dept. utilized water spray to dissipate some of the propane vapor under the transport before they were able to flare. The leak lasted for roughly 2 hours before flaring equipment could be set up and utilized. The flare was set up and remaining propane was burnt off prior to the transport and 3rd party vehicle being moved and the road re-opened.

When we refused to do so they stated they would take the cellphones out. However during the screening process the screener noticed cellphones and 2 tablet found the cellphones were wrapped in writing paper. The charging cord was wrapped around the phone. I ultimately decided to refuse the shipment due to the undeclared dangerous goods and the way they were ____ .

item.title: Report I-2024100114
item.description:
Report I-2024100114

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-05T12:22:11+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-13
  • City: KINGSPORT
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: SINDLE TRUCKING, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 76044
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: BAE Systems Ordnance Systems Inc. (OSI) is the operating contractor for Holston Army Ammunition Plant (HSAAP) located at 4509 West Stone Drive in Kingsport, Hawkins County, Tennessee. On September 13, 2024 a hose rupture during offload of a strong nitric acid tanker resulted in a release of acid to the environment. A description of the event is outlined below: The truck driver and operators started the transfer and then moved to observe from a safe location per standard operating procedure. Approximately 10 minutes after the transfer started, personnel observed a NOx cloud and nitric acid spray coming from the back of the tanker. After the wind shifted, the driver made the decision to approach the tanker and activate the emergency stop, ending the release. Upon further investigation after the incident, personnel found the transfer hose had failed. The total amount of nitric acid released from the tanker was 20,988 pounds. It is estimated that approximately 10,494 pounds of nitric acid drained to the spill basin for the tanker pad and into the wastewater collection system. Approximately 10,494 pounds sprayed onto the ground next to the tanker pad. None of the nitric acid traveled to the stormwater channels. Approximately 105 pounds of NOx was released during the event. A hazmat contractor was promptly hired to clean up the release.

item.title: Report I-2024090070
item.description:
Report I-2024090070

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-05T00:41:19+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-22
  • City: SANTA FE SPRINGS
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: TRIUMVIRATE ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Carrier picked up load from Shipper between 05:00 and 07:00 with no spilled material observed by Driver or other paries, drive to other scheduled stops which involved multiple loading events with no spills observed by Driver or other parties, load arrived back at home terminal at 11 :49 where it was not handled further until a leak was observed by another Worker at the home terminal at 13:08, spill containment trays deployed, other materials offloaded to access the leaking container which was near the front of the trailer, the container was laid down to stop the leak and to assess the source, container was overpacked, manifest updated, driveway and parking lot inspected for signs of leak which was not observed, concluded based on location of spill and volume that leak had begun shortly before observation, Shipper notified, and load sent to final destination on 09/29/2024 using the same EPA Manifest 017958543FLE. Source of leak found to be small round hole underneath drum; shape of hole was not conducive to damage from the used handling equipment, edges of hole were not pressed inward and not conducive to indication of a puncture, inner rim of the drum's bottom side displayed signs of wear as though metal was aged despite a newer layer of paint. Determined that bottom face had been painted over a weakened surface of the container and that the contents of the drum could have contributed to breaking through paint and an already degraded structural material.

item.title: Report E-2024110000
item.description:
Report E-2024110000

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-04T12:23:29+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-31
  • City: DALLAS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LDA experienced a UN2051 Nalco 1606A release from (3) 275-gallon poly totes. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct onsite cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 8 ounces of product released from the caps of all three totes. The caps on the totes were loose, resulting in material sloshing out in transit. The material impacted the tops of the totes and a 3” x 3” area of plywood in the trailer. The caps were tightened, and a slosh test was conducted on the totes to ensure there would not be further release. The impacted plywood, pads, and PPE were then containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

The impacted pallet wood, absorbents, and cardboard were placed into a second 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.description:
Report E-2024110002

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-04T12:23:29+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-25
  • City: SUWANEE
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On October 25, 2024, one (1) half-gallon (0.5) pail of nitric acid was damaged in transit and released approximately one-half gallon (0.5) of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel utilized hand tools, absorbents, and soda ash to remediate the nitric acid-impacted impacted pallet, cardboard boxes, and trailer floor. One (1) damaged jug of nitric acid was containerized into one (1) 5-gallon pail and labeled as hazardous. All impacted debris, spent absorbents, and PPE were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum.

item.title: Report E-2024110005
item.description:
Report E-2024110005

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-04T12:23:29+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-25
  • City: GLENPOOL
  • State: OK
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LTU experienced a UN2735 Evercat ZR-70 release from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.25 cup of product released to a 1’ x 6” area of the concrete dock floor and tote body due to a crack on the lid of the tote. The material was transferred from the damaged tote to a new one. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with impacted absorbents used to clean the spill into (4) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2024100739
item.description:
Report E-2024100739

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-04T12:23:29+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-24
  • City: PHILADELPHIA
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: During a routine inspection at Veolia's ten day in-transit facility in Philadelphia, PA, Veolia staff discovered a compromised container. Upon investigation, they found that inner packages had leaked through three outer containers and were generating heat through a chemical reaction with the absorbent material present. It was determined that 5 x 1 gallon inner packages in each of the three containers were not upright and had leaked through vented caps onto an absorbent. It was further determined the absorbent utilized by the shipper contained organic material which resulted in the reaction and heat generation. The material was repackaged with all inner packages up right and placed in individual plastic bags with inorganic cushioning and absorbent to prevent any reaction resulting in three 55 gallon drums and one 30 gallon drum. The original absorbent material was wetted, placed into containers and transported for disposal along with the repackaged packages.

UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED TWO INNER RETAIL PACKAGING BOXES CONTAINING DISPOSABLE VAPE CARTRIDGES WITH 5% NICOTINE WITHIN THOSE BOXES. THE VAPE CARTRIDGES ARE POWERED BY LITHIUM ION BATTERIES. THERE ARE A TOTAL OF TWENTY DISPOSABLE VAPE CARTRIDGES INSIDE THE BOX. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

  • City: JACKSONVILLE

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On October 22, 2024, one (1) 330-gallon tote of resin solution was punctured by a forklift and released approximately ten (10) gallons of product to the dock floor and pavement of the terminal yard. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the estimated ten (10) gallons of released product on the dock floor and pavement of the terminal yard, worked them in, and then collected the spent absorbents with hand tools. The contents of the damaged tote were transferred into one (1) new 330-gallon tote that was labeled as "Do Not Deliver" and staged for further handling by R+L personnel. One (1) 55-gallon drum and the empty 330-gallon poly tote were labeled appropriately and staged in the terminal's OS&D room

  • Description: At approximately 9:34 AM on 09/24/24, notification was received that the tank car was leaking product (Diesel Fuel) from the top and down the side. The car was located in our American Yard and our contractor, Haz-Mat Special Services, was contacted for repair and remediation. HMSS identified the issue as three of the six manway bolts were less than tool-tight. HMSS was able to tighten the bolts and resolved the leak.

When the employee returned to work on Monday, 9/23, he observed the material had leaked out of its container, through the wooden truck bed of the box truck and onto the asphalt on the ground under the truck. During clean up, it was observed that lots of liquid had been put into this container.

All the manways and retention pond were checked to verify no fuel had left the property. E3OMI pumped all of the liquid from the storm drains and basin. 21,840-gallons of gasoline impacted water was recovered and processed for recycling.

item.title: Report I-2024090044
item.description:
Report I-2024090044

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-04T12:23:29+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-06
  • City: JEANNETTE
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNIVAR SOLUTIONS USA INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Driver noticed product leaking as he was taking a break and notified supervision. The leak was coming from the crash/spill box area. The driver began to drive the equipment and was instructed by supervision to stop driving the equipment and pull into a safe area. The driver stopped and the local municipality's fire department and EHS arrived at the scene, as well as, a third party environmental clean-up company, McCutcheon's. The HCL was off-loaded into 10 totes, which were loaded into straight truck with a lift gate, approximately 1,600gallons were off-loaded into another Univar tanker and taken to the Univar Altoona plant, and the remaining product remained in the original tanker. The 10 totes and original tanker were taken to the Univar Solutions Bunola plant. Approximately 20 gallons of HCL was released. Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection conducted a site visit and provided a satisfactory rating for the response and clean up. PADEP #1410124
